III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures
Section • (2) The policies and procedures must cover at least all the
Description following areas:
1

• (f) Amount of financial support and how it is
disbursed. An agency may not withhold financial
support intended for the youth while the youth is
actively involved in the program.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency is withholding youth's IL stipends if curfew is broken or
chores aren't completed.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on August 6,
2025, and reported they had no additional information.
Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed face-to-face on
June 24, 2025. He stated he is not aware of any IL stipends that
have not been provided to Youth A. FCW stated there have been
occasions where there is a delay in providing those to Youth A but
that is due to her being frequently absent for days at a time. The
IL stipends are provided to Youth A when she returns to the IL
home.
Foster Care supervisor (FC supervisor) was interviewed face-
to-face on June 24, 2025. She stated all IL stipends have been
provided to Youth A. There has been a delay at times due to
Youth A repeatedly leaving the home and not returning for several
days at a time. The agency obtains youth signatures when IL
stipend checks are provided to ensure accurate recordkeeping.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face on June 24, 2025. Youth
A stated the agency has withheld her IL stipend checks in the past
but they always end up giving them to her later. When asked for
more detail she stated the occasions when she doesn’t receive
her check is due to her being in other locations and not coming
back when she is supposed to.
Documents reviewed:
• Agency handbook that states “youth understand their
stipend will be held if they refuse to follow program rules.
Youth agree to adhere to curfew rules by being present in
their placement by 9pm Sunday-Thursday and 11pm
Friday-Saturday.”
• April 2025-July 2025 documentation signed and dated by
Youth A and agency staff acknowledging IL stipend checks
were provided and received by Youth A.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of relevant documentation Youth A has
been provided all IL stipend checks. There were noted occasions
2

when the checks were not provided timely due to Youth A being
frequently absent from the IL home, however they are provided
upon her return.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements
Section • (3) An independent living home, staffed and operated by
Description the child placing agency, must be clean, safe, and
appropriate to the needs of the youth it serves.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There are safety and maintenance concerns with the IL home.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on August 6,
2025, and reported they had no additional information.
Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed face-to-face on
June 24, 2025. He stated he is not aware of any damage to the
home that would result in a safety concern. The agency addresses
any maintenance issue as they become aware. FCW stated he is
not aware of an instance where police raided the home.
Foster Care supervisor (FC supervisor) was interviewed face-
to-face on June 24, 2025. She stated the agency prioritizes the
safety and maintenance of the home. The air conditioner recently
broke, however a work order was put in right away and was fixed
within a few days. She stated the washing machine is in working
order, however the dryer is not. As a result, the agency has
clothes lines for youth to air dry their clothes or they have been
provided with the locations of laundromats if they prefer to use a
dryer.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face on June 24, 2025. She
stated she does not have any safety concerns related to the
condition of the IL home. She was asked about damage to the
home and her bedroom. She stated the only damage was a
broken top hinge on her bedroom closet, however the agency
repaired it. She was asked about any damage that may have been
caused as a result of a police raid, and she stated she wasn’t
aware of that happening.
Tour observation:
A tour of the facility occurred on June 24, 2025. Upon entering the
home there is a set of stairs leading to a landing and another set
of stairs that angles up to the right that enters the living room.
Only the first set of stairs leading to the landing is visible from the
doorway. Down the hall on the left are youth bedrooms and further
3

down the hall on the right is the kitchen area. There is a set of
stairs leading to the basement off the kitchen. There is a washer
and dryer in the basement. Staff noted the washer works but the
dryer does not. However, they have clothes lines for youth to hang
their clothes to dry if they choose. The house was observed to be
clean with no safety issues. There was no evidence indicating any
damage throughout the house. All youth bedrooms were also
observed and there was no visible damage.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. Based on completed
interviews and on-site walkthrough there is no evidence to support
this allegation. The IL home was viewed to be clean and no safety
concerns noted.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12505 Supervision
Section • (2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
Description supervision:
• (c) Provide the youth with a telephone number to
contact the agency on a 24-hour, 7-days-a-week
basis.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth returned to the IL home after curfew and was unable to
contact anyone to let her inside.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on August 6,
2025, and reported they had no additional information.
Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed face-to-face on
June 24, 2025. He stated Youth A has consistently left the IL
home for days at a time. On June 2, 2025, she sent him a text
message at 11:45pm indicating she couldn’t get in the house. He
clarified that she had been gone for a few days at that point and
there was no reason to believe she would be returning that night.
There is an incident report documenting this. FCW stated he was
sleeping at this time of night and didn’t see the message until the
following morning but indicated she only contacted him and did
not try to contact the staff on duty. FCW stated for safety and
security reasons, the IL home is locked during the night hours.
Foster Care supervisor (FC supervisor) was interviewed face-
to-face on June 24, 2025. She stated curfew is 11pm Friday and
Saturday and 9pm Sunday through Thursday. FC supervisor
stated Youth A has consistently violated curfew and been AWOL
on several occasions and the agency has filed numerous police
4

reports as well as incident reports. Due to the ongoing program
violations, the agency has put in their 30 day notice for Youth A to
be moved to another placement. FC supervisor stated the IL home
is staffed between the hours of 3pm-7am. During the night hours
the home is locked for safety and security reasons, however youth
are provided with an on-call number if they need to contact staff.
FC supervisor stated it was her understanding Youth A attempted
to return to the IL home very late in the evening on June 2, 2025,
and only attempted to contact FCW and not the on-call number as
they are instructed to do.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face on June 24, 2025. She
acknowledged there have been situations when she does not
follow the set curfew or return to the IL home as required. On June
2, 2025, she returned late at night, approximately 11:30pm, after
being absent for a few days and was not able to enter due to the
front door being locked. She stated she attempted to contact FCW
but there was no answer. Youth A was asked if she contacted the
on-call phone number provided by the agency and she stated she
did not.
Independent Living Staff 1 (IL Staff 1) was interviewed via
telephone on July 25, 2025. He stated Youth A has a lengthy
history of going AWOL from the IL house for multiple days at a
time and not having any communication with the agency while she
is gone. He stated for safety reasons the house is always locked.
The agency has set curfew hours and if youth want to return after
those established hours, they are able to call the on call phone. IL
Staff 1 stated he doesn’t recall having any contact with Youth A on
the evening of June 2, 2025.
Documents reviewed:
• Agency handbook states “youth agree to adhere to curfew
rules by being present in their placement by 9pm Sunday-
Thursday and 11pm Friday-Saturday.
• Incident report dated June 3, 2025, was reviewed and is
consistent with FCW and FC supervisor interviews.
• Agency policies/procedures and Youth Program statement
was reviewed. Agency on-call/after hours information
provided and signed by Youth A.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. On June 2, 2025, Youth A
returned to the IL home very late in the evening after being absent
for a few days and was not able to enter due to the door being
locked. She attempted to contact FCW who didn’t respond but
5

never attempted to call the on-call number as she was previously
instructed to do and is outlined in the agency intake packet.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
